Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Integrating Physiology and Genomics to Test for Local Adaptation in a Montane Ectotherm
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the processes determining color and size differences between western fence lizards occurring at high versus low elevations on mountains in California. High elevation lizards are darker and larger than low elevation lizards. Such differences in traits within a species are generally assumed to be genetically based and a result of adaptation to local environments. However, phenotypic differences can also result from the effects of different environmental conditions on development. The researchers will use a combination of physiological experiments and genomic analyses to identify whether color and size differences in western fence lizards are a consequence of natural selection or phenotypic plasticity. Results will provide critical insights into the role and evolutionary advantages of environmentally dependent phenotypic differences in heterogeneous environments. In addition, the project includes day-long educational workshops targeting young girls interested in STEM fields and development of an interactive exhibit on lizards for a local museum.

This study focuses on a phenotypic cline in the western fence lizard (Sceloporus occidentalis) along an elevational gradient in the Sierra Nevada Mountains of California. By combining techniques from genomics, functional ecology, and transcriptomics, this research will develop a comprehensive picture of the origin and function of high elevation phenotypes in western fence lizards. The researchers plan to evaluate the influence of temperature and day length on juvenile phenotypes, and to identify candidate genomic regions implicated in phenotypic differentiation. Juvenile lizards will be reared in a laboratory common garden experiment with treatments that mimic conditions at high and low elevation. This experimental design will decouple the genetic and environmental constituents of phenotype, and also shed light on the functional implications of trait differences. By comparing gene expression profiles of lizards reared in native and non-native conditions, fixed and plastic responses to environmental conditions at both organismal and genomic levels will be identified.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of our research was to disentangle genetic and environmental constituents of lizard phenotypes along an elevation gradient in Yosemite National Park. We focused on populations distributed along the Grand Canyon of the Tuolumne River in northern Yosemite. These populations exhibit differences in size and color along the gradient that might confer fitness advantages in certain environments. At high elevations, where the environment is cooler, lizards are larger and more melanistic. Cool conditions limit potential activity time because lizards choose to be inactive when they cannot behaviorally thermoregulate. Larger body sizes might enable lizards to extend activity by allowing them to retain heat and melanistic coloration might help lizards become active sooner by allowing them to absorb solar radiation and accelerate heating rates. At low elevations, where the environment is warmer and potential activity time is less constrained by cool temperatures, lizards are smaller and lighter-colored.

We reared 89 hatchling lizards under controlled lab conditions to directly evaluate the impact of activity times on lizard phenotypes. We collected 5 low elevation and 8 high elevation pregnant females, allowed them to lay eggs in the lab, and incubated eggs under identical conditions. Then we distributed hatchlings from low and high elevations among two treatments: a short activity period (6 hours) and a long activity period (12 hours). We tracked lizard phenotypes (growth rates, body size, color, behavior) by taking repeated measurements from each individual each week. At the termination of the experiment, we collected multiple tissue types for gene expression analysis.

We found that some components of hatchling phenotypes were genetically-based and some components were environmentally-based. Differences in body sizes and growth rates between low and high elevation were genetically-based. Differences in color were environmentally based, meaning that hatchlings from the same populations that were reared in different activity treatments were different in color. Behavior, specifically the proportion of time hatchlings chose to be active, was genetically-based; high elevation hatchlings capitalized on long activity periods, while low elevation hatchlings were more conservative. Differences in behavior might be linked to differences in the cost of thermoregulation in different environments in nature. Low elevation environments have a higher abundance of predators, so the costs of increased activity might outweigh the benefits. The potential costs of predation may not outweigh the benefits of increased activity at high elevation, were activity restricts are already restricted by cooler temperatures.

Intellectual merit: Our study builds on foundational work in phenotypic evolution and facilitates a direct link between activity time and phenotypes. Activity time restrictions are predicted to be the primary stressor of ectotherm populations facing climate-change-induced warming. Our work also dissects mechanisms that produce intraspecific varition. Mechanisms of intraspecific variation in traits is a research priority and essential for predicting species responses to climate change.

Broader impacts: Our research program contained field- and lab-based components, which translated to abundant opportunities for outreach, technical training, and mentorship. As part of the field component we trained 30 individuals in field data collection and animal handling. We also conveyed research objectives and methods to the general public (visitors to Yosemite). Four volunteers continued on to secure employment that is related to biological research. As part of the lab component we trained 8 individuals in lab data collection and animal husbandry.
